item.title: Iran Leverages Oil to Court Other U.S. Rivals During Pandemic
item.description: Isolated in the midst of a global pandemic, Iran is using its sanctioned oil and energy expertise to garner favor and financial gain from two other nations shunned by the U.S.: Syria and Venezuela.

item.title: Egypt Gets $2.77 Billion IMF Loan as Coronavirus Hurts Economy
item.description: The International Monetary Fund approved Monday a $2.77 billion loan to Egypt in an attempt to prevent economic collapse in the Middle East’s most populous nation due to the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: China Fires Official After New Coronavirus Cases Emerge in Wuhan Community
item.description: Chinese authorities in Wuhan fired a local official after six new Covid-19 cases were confirmed over the weekend in a housing complex under his jurisdiction.

item.title: Saudi Arabia Imposes Austerity Measures as Its Economy Founders
item.description: The kingdom said it would triple its value-added tax rate and eliminate allowances for state workers, adopting austerity measures aimed at boosting state finances battered by the coronavirus and lower oil prices.

item.title: While Big Oil Pulls Back, Mexico's President Bets on Pemex
item.description: As global oil companies try to make savings, Mexican President Andrés Manuel López Obrador is focusing much of the country’s limited financial firepower on its state-run oil company.

item.title: As Lockdown Eases, India's Migrant Workers Begin to Head Home
item.description: Millions are struggling with whether to stay put in crowded cities or return to their home villages, a question that could determine both how quickly the country’s economy recovers and how widely the coronavirus spreads.
